title: SSH Basics and Key Authentication
question: How does SSH key authentication work? How do you set it up?
answer: SSH key authentication uses a public-private key pair. Generate keys with ssh-keygen, copy the public key (~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub) to the server's ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file using ssh-copy-id. The private key stays on your machine and should never be shared. Key auth is more secure than passwords and enables passwordless login.
explanation: SSH is the primary way to access remote servers securely. Understanding key-based authentication is essential for DevOps work, as it's used for server administration, Git operations, CI/CD pipelines, and automated deployments.

codeExamples.label: Generate and deploy SSH keys
codeExamples.code:
# Generate new SSH key pair
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C 'your@email.com'

# Copy public key to server
ssh-copy-id user@server.example.com

# Or manually copy the key
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub | ssh user@server 'cat >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys'

# Connect to server
ssh user@server.example.com

codeExamples.label: SSH config file for easier access
codeExamples.code:
# Create/edit ~/.ssh/config
Host prod-server
  HostName 192.168.1.100
  User deploy
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/prod_key
  Port 22

# Now connect with just:
ssh prod-server

# Run command on remote server
ssh prod-server 'df -h'

Sharing or committing private keys to version control
